Literature Review: Induced resistance in fruits and vegetables represents a sophisticated host physiological response aimed at limiting the development of postharvest diseases. This mechanism is particularly crucial given the perishable nature of harvested produce, which is susceptible to desiccation, increased respiration during ripening, and colonization by postharvest fungal pathogens. The concept of induced resistance involves the activation of biochemical processes within the plant that enhance its defensive capabilities against decay-causing fungi. This is achieved by modulating the ripening and senescence processes, thereby maintaining the produce in a state of heightened resistance. Recent advancements in scientific tools have significantly improved our understanding of the physiological changes in plants that contribute to induced resistance, offering new avenues for disease control in postharvest produce. One of the key benefits of induced resistance is its ability to slow the decline of innate immunity after harvest. This is accompanied by an increase in the production of defensive responses that directly inhibit plant pathogens. Such responses include the accumulation of phenols and antioxidant compounds, which not only enhance the plant's resistance to pathogens but also improve the quality and appearance of the produce. The effectiveness of induced resistance is influenced by several factors, including the host's maturity and the stage of ripening. These factors can limit the expression of induced-resistance processes, highlighting the importance of considering the physiological state of the produce when implementing strategies to enhance its resistance to postharvest diseases. Various treatments have been explored to induce resistance in harvested fruits and vegetables. These include the application of chemical elicitors, physical treatments, and biological agents, each of which can activate different pathways of the plant's immune system. For instance, the use of salicylic acid and jasmonic acid as chemical elicitors has been shown to enhance the production of defensive compounds in several fruit species. Similarly, physical treatments such as UV-C irradiation and controlled atmosphere storage have been effective in inducing resistance by modulating the plant's physiological responses. Biological agents, including beneficial microorganisms, have also been utilized to stimulate the plant's immune system, offering a sustainable approach to disease control. The integration of these treatments into postharvest management practices can significantly reduce the incidence of fungal colonization, thereby extending the shelf life of fruits and vegetables. However, the success of these strategies depends on a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms of induced resistance and the factors that influence its effectiveness. Future research should focus on elucidating these mechanisms and developing innovative treatments that can be easily integrated into existing postharvest management systems. In conclusion, induced resistance offers a promising strategy for controlling postharvest diseases in fruits and vegetables. By enhancing the plant's natural defense mechanisms, it is possible to reduce the reliance on chemical fungicides, thereby promoting the production of safer and higher-quality produce. The continued advancement of scientific tools and the development of novel treatments will be crucial in realizing the full potential of induced resistance in postharvest disease management.
